abstracts.cdata!:
This is the environmental assessment for
            the Sevastopol Heat Supply Project, which reviews the
            environmental legislation, verifying that the emission
            standards of the former Soviet Union, are still valid in
            Ukraine. Nonetheless, only standards for carbon monoxide,
            and nitrogen oxides emissions - from small boilers, burning
            different fuels - are available, and, no standards seem to
            be available for sulfur emissions, nor does any legislation
            cover larger boilers. Emissions from the current district
            heating estimates, are based on the energy situation in
            1993, and fuel consumption is based on information available
            from Sevteploenergo. Although, it is expected that fuel
            consumption will decrease, resulting in improved
            environmental conditions, mitigation include the change in
            fuel, from coal to gas, or oil, and the exchange of old
            boilers, which will improve the district heating system, and
            allow for consumers' energy savings. Emissions of
            carbon, nitrogen, and sulfur dioxides into the atmosphere
            will be reduced, limiting the emissions of greenhouse gases,
            causing less acidification, while improving also, the local
            atmosphere. Disposal of insulation materials are of great
            concern, thus new insulation materials will not contain CFC
            and HCFC. Though it is believed that asbestos exist, only
            during rehabilitation works will it possible to accurately
            minimize risks by containing asbestos material.
